page.title: 02River Wey and Watermeadows.
page.content: The river Wey is crossed by four roads very recently the stonework of the narrow bridge carrying the B3004 was conserved during widening. Public foot paths cross the Wey at 5 places and from paths alongside the walker sees reeds, rushes and balsams under alder trees, or the open lake of Waterside. Formerly 3 watermills flourished, and a highly engineered system of water meadows was in operation to raise grass productivity. Initiated probably in the 1650's, the watermeadows were irrigated from the river by linked channels, small stone aqueducts and long stretches of stone work, with hatches to allow or prevent the flow. It was a labour intensive system controlled by the water baliffs and 'drowners', and persisted into this century. The urge in the 1980's to conserve this evidence is very strong.
